value.title: Making a Dart web app offline-capable: 3 lines of code

content.subtitle: Have you ever tried to load a web application (maybe a game or a measurement converter) and couldn’t use it because the network was down…

paragraphs.text: Making a Dart web app offline-capable: 3 lines of code

paragraphs.name: 654a
paragraphs.text: Have you ever tried to load a web application (maybe a game or a measurement converter) and couldn’t use it because the network was down? That’s an awful experience, but luckily we have the technology to make such apps available for our users.

For most apps and games, this can be done with 3 lines of Dart code and 1 command in the terminal. In this short article I’ll guide you through the steps, and make sure that you can always play Pop, Pop, Win!

paragraphs.name: b6fa
paragraphs.text: Pop, Pop, Win! — a Minesweeper implementation in Dart

paragraphs.name: c6a1
paragraphs.text: Service workers

paragraphs.name: 48c8
paragraphs.text: A service worker is a JavaScript file that runs in the background. It can control the web page or the site it is associated with, intercepting and modifying navigation and resource requests, and caching resources in a very granular fashion.

paragraphs.name: a2a7
paragraphs.text: It is a non-intrusive web technology: service workers can improve the user experience if the browser supports them, but the site can operate just fine in their absence (with the default web behavior). This is a useful property that enables progressive web applications (PWA), where you can provide more advanced features to the majority of the users, while making sure that the rest aren’t locked out.

paragraphs.name: e932
paragraphs.text: As a background processing thread, a service worker can help with:

paragraphs.name: 8ce2
paragraphs.text: offline mode (fetching resources from cache while the network is down)

paragraphs.name: baea
paragraphs.text: caching strategies (for near-instant cached responses that can be updated later with fresh content)

paragraphs.name: 14a2
paragraphs.text: push notifications (like in a mobile app)

paragraphs.name: 155e
paragraphs.text: messaging (if the application is open on multiple tabs)

paragraphs.name: 2e5d
paragraphs.text: The important feature for our offline gaming experience is this: we would like to play Pop, Pop, Win!, and not meet this dinosaur:

paragraphs.name: f3f7
paragraphs.text: Fun fact: you can play with that dinosaur by pushing the up arrow key.

paragraphs.name: 7b35
paragraphs.text: Progressive web app with Dart

paragraphs.name: e4fd
paragraphs.text: Supporting offline mode requires roughly the following:

paragraphs.name: bc5d
paragraphs.text: Determining which resources to put in the cache for offline use.

paragraphs.name: 954d
paragraphs.text: Creating a service worker that prepares a cache of these resources.

paragraphs.name: 01c2
paragraphs.text: Registering the service worker, so that subsequent requests can be served from the offline cache (in case the network is down).
In that service worker, pre-populating the offline cache with the URLs, and also handling the appropriate fetch request either from the cache, or from the network.

paragraphs.name: 5d38
paragraphs.text: Making sure that the service worker detects changes to the app or static assets, and puts the new version in the cache.

paragraphs.name: 8b48
paragraphs.text: While the above list may sound a bit scary, we have a pwa package in Dart that does most of the work for us, providing a high-level API and automating most of the work.

paragraphs.name: df21
paragraphs.text: Changes in your application

paragraphs.name: de77
paragraphs.text: Import the pwa package in your pubspec.yaml:

paragraphs.name: bc89
paragraphs.text:
dependencies:
  pwa: ^0.1.2

paragraphs.name: f56c
paragraphs.text: After running pub get, add the client to your web/main.dart:

paragraphs.name: ad78
paragraphs.text: import ‘package:pwa/client.dart’ as pwa;

paragraphs.name: 36b8
4ac2
paragraphs.text: The above code handles item 3 from the above list by registering the service worker (which we will create in the following step). Right now we don’t use the Client instance for anything else, but as the pwa package gets new features, it may become useful for other purposes.

paragraphs.name: 2acb
paragraphs.text: Automatically generated progressive web application

paragraphs.name: e65d
paragraphs.text: The pwa package provides code generation that handles items 1–2 and 4–5 from the above list. To ensure proper cache use (both populating and invalidating the cache) use the following workflow:

paragraphs.name: a2b1
paragraphs.text:
Build your web app with all of the static resources landing in build/web:
pub build

Run pwa’s code generator to scan (or rescan) your offline assets:
pub run pwa

paragraphs.name: 0aff
paragraphs.text:
Build your project again, because you need to have your (new) pwa.dart file compiled:
pub build

paragraphs.name: a480
paragraphs.text: These steps produce a file named lib/pwa/offline_urls.g.dart that contains a list of the offline URLs to be cached. The .g.dart extension indicates that the file is generated and may be overwritten automatically by pwa’s code generator tool.

paragraphs.name: 7ea0
paragraphs.text: On the first run, this workflow generates the web/pwa.dart file that contains your service worker with reasonable defaults. You can modify this file (to customize the offline URLs or use the high-level APIs, for example) because the code generator won’t change or override it again.

paragraphs.name: 74b7
paragraphs.text: Caveats

paragraphs.name: 61f3
paragraphs.text: While Dartium is great for most web development, at the moment it’s hard to use with service workers. We recommend using Chrome or Firefox instead.

paragraphs.name: f4eb
paragraphs.text: Cache invalidation is one of the hardest problems in computer science. The underlying Web Cache API provides some guarantees, and the pwa library goes to a great length to gracefully handle the edge cases, but don’t treat the cache as reliable storage for anything really important. Make use of the cache when it is available, and fail gracefully when it’s not.

paragraphs.name: 74d9
paragraphs.text: Try it out

paragraphs.name: 9a67
paragraphs.text: You can now deploy the new version of your application. Or try the offline Pop, Pop, Win! game.

paragraphs.name: 7c10
paragraphs.text: After opening the game and playing one round, shut down your wi-fi or unplug the network cable, and then reload (or retype the URL). If you’re using Chrome or Firefox, your game should be up and running. Good luck, have fun!
